*[Bug 18919] [<-.POSIXlt and [[<-.POSIXlt do not reconcile time zones of 'x', 'value' before subassignment*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18919>

--- Comment #9 from Suharto Anggono (<mailto:suharto_anggono@yahoo.com|suharto_anggono@yahoo.com>) ---
(In reply to Mikael Jagan from comment #7)
That's my point. Why does `as.POSIXlt` behave like that and subassignment to
`POSIXlt` behave differently?

But, yes, `c.POSIXlt` sets a precedent. It has been like that even before `tz`
argument has effect when `as.POSIXlt` is applied to `POSIXlt` object.

Be aware that conversion to `POSIXct` may introduce loss of precision of
fractional seconds.

Because the conversion to `POSIXct` is skipped when `value` is a `POSIXlt`
object with identical `tzone` attribute as `x`, with

    x1 <- as.POSIXlt(.POSIXct(0, tz = "UTC")

,

    x1[1L] <- as.POSIXlt("2006-02-20 11:16:16.683", tz = "UTC")

and

    x1[1L] <- as.POSIXlt("2006-02-20 11:16:16.683", tz = "GMT")

give different results.

Be also aware that the change also affects `value` that is not a `POSIXlt`
object. In particular, subassigned character string will be interpreted as
being in the current timezone.

After

    x1 <- as.POSIXlt(.POSIXct(0, tz = "UTC")
    x1[1L] <- "1970-01-01 00:00:00"

, what is in `x1` is not the beginning of 1970 if the current timezone is
different from UTC.

It would be good if a recipe to reproduce old behavior is also given.

The timezone reconciliation is not even mentioned in NEWS. The NEWS just says
"now rebalance as they should".

By r88463, the change has been ported to R patched. I suggest not porting the
timezone reconciliation. Even if it matches what one expects, it can be seen as
change of meaning. I think a minor version of R should not have it.

text:
*[Bug 18919] [<-.POSIXlt and [[<-.POSIXlt do not reconcile time zones of 'x', 'value' before subassignment*
https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18919

--- Comment #10 from Mikael Jagan (jaganmn@mcmaster.ca) ---
(In reply to Suharto Anggono from comment #9)
> That's my point. Why does `as.POSIXlt` behave like that and subassignment to
> `POSIXlt` behave differently?
> 

Indeed.  It certainly *seems* like a bug, that `as.POSIXlt(<POSIXlt>, tz=)`
sets the `tzone` attribute without checking whether that might leave the object
in an invalid state due to inconsistent list components `isdst`, `zone`, and
`gmtoff`.  My feeling is that such calls to `as.POSIXlt` should behave as
`c.POSIXlt` and (now) `[<-.POSIXlt` and `[[<-.POSIXlt` by checking and where
necessary performing a reconciliation.

It would be nice to have a way to reconcile time zones without losing the extra
precision afforded by `POSIXlt`.  In principle, couldn't one compute the offset
number of seconds, add that to `<POSIXlt>$sec`, then rebalance?

> But, yes, `c.POSIXlt` sets a precedent. It has been like that even before
> `tz` argument has effect when `as.POSIXlt` is applied to `POSIXlt` object.
> 
> Be aware that conversion to `POSIXct` may introduce loss of precision of
> fractional seconds.
> 
> Because the conversion to `POSIXct` is skipped when `value` is a `POSIXlt`
> object with identical `tzone` attribute as `x`, with
> 
>     x1 <- as.POSIXlt(.POSIXct(0, tz = "UTC")
> 
> ,
> 
>     x1[1L] <- as.POSIXlt("2006-02-20 11:16:16.683", tz = "UTC")
> 
> and
> 
>     x1[1L] <- as.POSIXlt("2006-02-20 11:16:16.683", tz = "GMT")
> 
> give different results.
> 

Loss of precision is acceptable to me if the alternative is an invalid object. 
But indeed this point is important and could be better documented *at least* in
the NEWS.

> Be also aware that the change also affects `value` that is not a `POSIXlt`
> object. In particular, subassigned character string will be interpreted as
> being in the current timezone.
> 
> After
> 
>     x1 <- as.POSIXlt(.POSIXct(0, tz = "UTC")
>     x1[1L] <- "1970-01-01 00:00:00"
> 
> , what is in `x1` is not the beginning of 1970 if the current timezone is
> different from UTC.
> 

The intermediate coercion to `POSIXct` does not specify a time zone, so the
current time zone is used.  That behaviour was chosen to be consistent with
`c.POSIXlt`, which seemed desirable.

> It would be good if a recipe to reproduce old behavior is also given.
> 

The old behaviour produced an invalid object.  Under R 4.4, the subassignment
in your example above gave `x1` such that `x1$zone` is the current time zone
(`"EST"` for me) while `attr(x1, "tzone")` is `"UTC"`, hence inconsistent.  Can
you clarify your use for such a recipe?  In general, I would want users to fix
rather than preserve code relying on invalid objects.

> The timezone reconciliation is not even mentioned in NEWS. The NEWS just
> says "now rebalance as they should".
> 

Yes, that seems insufficient ...

> By r88463, the change has been ported to R patched. I suggest not porting
> the timezone reconciliation. Even if it matches what one expects, it can be
> seen as change of meaning. I think a minor version of R should not have it.

I would tend to agree with you.

I'm very grateful for your additional comments, Suharto.

*[Bug 18938] New: seq.Date inconsistent on whether to= can be a string*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18938>

            Bug ID: 18938
           Summary: seq.Date inconsistent on whether to= can be a string
           Product: R
           Version: R-devel (trunk)
          Hardware: All
                OS: All
            Status: UNCONFIRMED
          Severity: normal
          Priority: P5
         Component: Misc
          Assignee: <mailto:R-core@R-project.org|R-core@R-project.org>
          Reporter: <mailto:michaelchirico4@gmail.com|michaelchirico4@gmail.com>

c.f.

```
seq(as.Date("2025-01-01"), "2025-01-07")
# [1] "2025-01-01" "2025-01-02" "2025-01-03" "2025-01-04" "2025-01-05"
"2025-01-06" "2025-01-07"

## vs.

seq(as.Date("2025-01-01"), "2025-01-07", by=1)
# Error in <http://seq.int|seq.int>(from = unclass(from), to = unclass(to), by = by) : 
#   'to' must be a finite number
# In addition: Warning message:
# In seq.Date(as.Date("2025-01-01"), "2025-01-07", by = 1) :
#   NAs introduced by coercion
```

I think automatic conversion to `Date` is quite appealing, much like
`DateVector >= "2025-01-01"` 'just works', so it would be good to have it
supported.

For "ragged" (not equally-spaced) `by=`, we already have `as.POSIXlt` coercion
so this works too:

```
seq(as.Date('2025-01-01'), '2025-08-01', by='month')
# [1] "2025-01-01" "2025-02-01" "2025-03-01" "2025-04-01" "2025-05-01"
"2025-06-01" "2025-07-01" "2025-08-01"
```

```
specified
seq(Sys.time(), '2025-10-22 00:00:00', by='months')
# Error in seq.POSIXt(Sys.time(), "2025-10-22 00:00:00", by = "months") : 
#   'to' must be a "POSIXt" object
```

--- Comment #3 from Michael Chirico (<mailto:michaelchirico4@gmail.com|michaelchirico4@gmail.com>) ---
Created attachment 3528
  --> <https://bugs.r-project.org/attachment.cgi?id=3528&action=edit>
Use as.Date() coercion in more places in seq.Date

Here's one approach.

I'm fairly confident we could drop the `as.Date()` coercion when `from` or `to`
are missing -- there, S3 dispatch should guarantee the one `from`/`to` argument
present inherits from Date.

Kept here for transparency/clarity.

Testing on GHA:

<https://github.com/r-devel/r-svn/pull/207>
